abstract.text: Investigate why your universal links are opening in Safari instead of your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: use
, an associated domains service, to link directly to content within your app without routing through Safari or your website.
If your app is installed, a universal link will open in your app.
If it is not installed, the link will open in your default web browser, where your site handles the rest.
If you are unfamiliar with universal links and how to support them in your code, see
and
This document outlines how to:

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Use universal links on your site

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Use universal links on your site

inlineContent.text: To test your universal links behavior, paste a link into your Notes app and long-press  it (iOS) or control-click it (macOS) to see your options for following the link.
If universal links have been configured correctly, the option to open in app and in Safari will both show up.
The option you choose will set the default behavior for your device when following universal links from this domain in the future.
To change this default choice, repeat the same steps and choose a different option.

Entering the URL directly into Safari’s address bar will never open the app. Safari will respect this action as direct navigation. As long as the user is on your domain after navigating there directly, your site will show a banner to open your app.
On iOS, you can additionally test your universal links with the associated domains diagnostic tests in Developer settings through these steps:
Turn on Developer Mode in Settings. Read
for more help.
In Settings > Developer, scroll to the section labeled Universal Links and turn on Associated Domains Development.
Open Diagnostics and type in your full URL. You will receive feedback on whether this link is valid for an installed app.
If your universal links are invalid, your
may be configured incorrectly.
Using the Signing and Capabilities tab in Xcode, verify the app has the Associated Domains capability which contains
in the form of:
A common problem is caused by using a domain in your
that doesn’t have an AASA file hosted in the correct location.
Make sure your domains and AASA file paths match.
To match a root domain and all subdomains with a wildcard, an AASA file should be hosted at:
This will only work with the root domain of
and subdomains that are matched with the wildcard
This will not work with specific subdomains like
or
To match a specific subdomain, an AASA file should be hosted at:
This will only work with
Each specific subdomain in your
should have its own matching AASA file path.
Domains in your
can’t contain a port number. For example,
will not open your app.

content.text: Use universal links on your site

inlineContent.text: To use a universal link to open your app while already browsing in Safari, use a different subdomain. Reasons for this could be completing a questionnaire or choosing to sign in.
If a universal link has the same domain as the previous navigation, Safari will expect the user wants to continue navigating within the browser.
Review
for more information.
For an example of when to use subdomains, consider an app with the root domain
and an AASA containing:

code: "comment" : "Matches any URL with a path that starts with /login/."

inlineContent.text: In Safari, if a user is browsing your site and choosing a login button with the link
, the link will not be opened in the app.
Safari will continue navigation in the browser even though the path matches the component above since the domain did not change.
To avoid this:
Add a subdomain such as
to your associated domains in the Signing and Capabilities tab in Xcode.
Host an AASA at:
Give the login button a link of:
Using a different subdomain prevents Safari from treating the link as navigation, so it will open in the link in your app.
If your universal links are still not opening in your app, take a closer look at your HTTP response headers and AASA content.
You can do this by printing both the HTTP response headers and AASA JSON contents in Terminal using
If you see a 301 or 302 HTTP response status code, your site is doing an HTTP redirect, which is not supported when hosting the AASA file.
The file must be directly reachable without any redirects.
Instead of hosting your AASA at your root domain and redirecting to serve a subdomain, host your AASA at each domain and subdomain included in your
For example, if you have a subdomain like
and the wildcard
, host one AASA file here for the subdomain:
and one here for the wildcard:
Redirection is allowed, although not preferred, when opening universal links from another app.
If the link tapped on by the user is not a universal link but redirects to one, the user will be routed through Safari to the app.
If you see a 403 or 404 HTTP error, your site denied access.
Generally, this happens when the AASA file path is not publicly accessible from all IP addresses or your site is blocked for some other reason.
Confirm your website’s configuration allows direct access to the AASA file in the
directory, in all geographical locations, from any IP address.
Specific IP addresses and ranges are not published as they cannot be guaranteed.
Verify the format of your AASA file. It should contain either an
of
and an
of
, as shown in
, or fields
of type
and
of type
(matching an older format). Don’t mix and match these formats or universal links won’t work.
Here’s the the recommended format:

code: "comment": "Matches any URL beginning with /path/1/ and instructs the system not to open it as a universal link"

inlineContent.text: While this is the older format:
To verify that your AASA is in a valid format and pattern matches correctly, use the built-in
tool on a Mac.
Running
in Terminal shows the available commands, including
and
You can use these commands in Terminal by:
Running
to check that the AASA JSON can be downloaded successfully.
Running
to check the contents of a downloaded
AASA file.
Verify that your domains match with
and your URL path pattern matches with the JSON with
. If both are successful, you will get a confirmation message.
For an app containing
and the AASA shown above, here is an example of using
where “s” is the service, “a” is the App ID, and “d” is the domain:

code: { s = applinks, a = ABCD123.com.example.app, d = example.com }:

inlineContent.text: Since the pattern
is included in the AASA, the JSON has successfully pattern matched and is verified. For the path
, since it is set to be excluded in the AASA, you would see a message confirming the exclusion:
If you see this message for a URL path that is not excluded, your AASA has not been matched. Take a look at the
section for more information.
If the output from
in the section
is showing invalid universal links, take a sysdiagnose on a device with the app installed by following the linked instructions for each platform in
After you have opened the sysdiagnose, open the
file.
Search for your
to see the information for your
as shown in the following example.
: Shows the user’s decision to open links in your app or in Safari.
Review
for more information.
: Specifies if the Apple-managed content delivery network (CDN) has approved your universal links and pattern matched successfully.
If it is
, your universal links are working correctly.
If it is
or
, please ensure you are allowing full access to all IP addresses and the domain is included in your associated domains.
For more information, review
: Specifies the last time Apple’s CDN requested your site for your AASA and when it will check again.
When your app is installed on a device, Apple’s CDN requests your AASA file.
For the CDN to successfully cache the file, it must be hosted on a domain that is available to all IP addreses and ranges, does not redirect, and is not blocked by access policies.
When testing, if you’re running your app from Xcode, using a server that is unreachable from the public internet, or testing changes faster than Apple’s CDN can cache them, use an alternate
mode as described in
This allows you to bypass Apple’s CDN and pulls your AASA directly from your domain.
On iOS 14 and later, Apple’s CDN retrieves and caches the AASA file.
When your app is installed, devices download the file from the CDN immediately.
Devices check for updates approximately once per week after app installation.
To download a newer version of the AASA file, reinstall the app. There is no direct CDN invalidation option.
Made minor changes, added note for port numbers.
First published.
